Authors:
Duan Romportl, Anna Vogeler, Marco Tschapka, Ivan Horáček,
Javier Juste, Steven M Goodman, Tereza Stribna, Pavel Hulva, Petr
Benda
Title:
Pan African phylogeography and palaeodistribution of
rousettine fruit bats: Ecogeographic correlation with Pleistocene
climate vegetation cycles
Keywords:
African phylogeography, expansion‐contraction paradigm,
forest refugia, fruit bats, island evolution, Last Glacial Maximum,
pluvial‐drought cycles, Rousettus, species distribution modelling,
stepping‐stone dispersal
Abstract:
The impact of Pleistocene climate oscillations on tropical
biomes is associated with changes to the extent of forest cover. Fruit
bats presumably participated in woodland expansions during wet periods
through their roles in pollination and seed dispersal. We hypothesized
that phylogeographic patterns of Rousettus on continental Africa and
adjacent islands should show a signature of pluvial‐drought cycles,
involving demographic expansions and contractions. Moreover, as these
bats are highly mobile, we aim to understand the role of insular effects
and potential ecotypic variation.
